greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest number m > 1 such that m^(p-1)-1 is divisible by p^2, where p = n-th prime.
comment: Using Fermat's little theorem twice, it is easy to see that m=p^2-1 solves this problem for all odd primes p. In fact, there appear to be exactly p-1 values of m with 1 <= m <= p^2 for which m^(p-1) == 1 (mod p^2). See A096082 for the related open problem. - _T. D. Noe_, Aug 24 2008

That there are exactly p-1 values of 1 <= m <= p^2 for which m^(p-1) == 1 (mod p^2) follows immediately from Hensel's lifting lemma and Fermat's little theorem - every solution mod p corresponds to a unique solution mod p^2. - _Phil Carmody_, Jan 10 2011
For n > 2, prime(n) does not divide a(n)^2 - 1, so a(n) is the smallest m > 1 such that (m^(prime(n)-1) - 1)/(m^2 - 1) == 0 (mod prime(n)^2). - _Thomas Ordowski_, Nov 24 2018
reference: P. Ribenboim, The New Book of Prime Number Records, Springer, 1996, 345-349.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: For n=3, p=5 is the third prime and 5^2 = 25 divides 7^4 - 1 = 2400.
program: (PARI) a(n) = my(p=prime(n)); for(a=2, oo, if(Mod(a, p^2)^(p-1)==1, return(a))) \\ _Felix Fröhlich_, Nov 24 2018
results.author: _Felice Russo_
